title: Incarcerated Inguinal Hernia
diagnosis_topic: Irreducible inguinal hernia with risk of strangulation
setup_script: “A 60-year-old man with a longstanding right inguinal hernia presents to the emergency department with acute right groin pain and a bulge that he cannot reduce. He also reports nausea and vomiting. On exam, you note a tender, non-reducible mass in the right inguinal canal. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 135/85 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.6 °C.
No peritonitis; abdomen soft, mild distention, bowel sounds present.
Tender, non-reducible mass in right inguinal canal; skin erythematous, no necrosis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident attempts gentle manual reduction (taxis) after analgesia/Trendelenburg

dynamic_flow.reply: Ultrasound shows incarcerated small bowel loop with venous congestion but preserved arterial flow.
Patient develops worsening pain, tachycardia HR 120, new fever 38.5 °C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident prepares patient NPO, places IV fluids, and administers broad-spectrum antibiotics
If resident proceeds to emergent inguinal exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: A standard groin incision is made over the inguinal canal. The external oblique aponeurosis is opened, cord structures isolated, and the hernia sac is identified and opened. A strangulated loop of small bowel is encountered.
The loop shows patchy necrosis with dusky appearance and loss of peristalsis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident chooses to enlarge exposure
dynamic_flow.reply: Conversion to midline laparotomy is performed for safe reduction and resection.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs small bowel resection
dynamic_flow.reply: The nonviable segment is resected with primary anastomosis using stapled or hand-sewn technique, depending on stability and contamination.
Because of contamination, hernia repair is performed with primary tissue approximation without mesh placement.
Groin incision closed in layers; abdomen closed primarily after irrigation. Temporary abdominal closure may be used if instability present.
Patient develops peritonitis, septic shock requiring vasopressors.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses elective vs. emergent repair
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner asks: “How do you counsel patients with reducible hernias to prevent this scenario?”
Nasogastric tube until bowel function returns, IV antibiotics continued, early ambulation, DVT prophylaxis, and avoidance of heavy lifting for 4–6 weeks.
Reinforces recognition of recurrence, contralateral hernia risk, and importance of weight control.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of incarcerated hernia and risk of strangulation
Decision-making regarding attempted reduction vs. emergent surgery
Appropriate preoperative management (IV fluids, antibiotics, NPO)
Operative management: resection of non-viable bowel, avoidance of mesh in contaminated field
Postoperative care and counseling for prevention of recurrence
